name: Battle River #3
location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1969, and is one section of a three unit station and has a maximum capacity of 149MW.

name: Battle River #4
location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
info: Battle river power station has been in operation since 1975, and is one section of a three unit station and has a maximum capacity of 155MW.

name: Battle River #5
location: 12 Miles South Hwy 855, Paintearth County No. 18, AB T0B 1N0
info: Battle River Power Station has been in operation since 1981 and is one section of a three unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 385MW.

name: Genesee #1
info: Unit 1 of the Genesee Power Station has been in operation since 1994. It has a maximum capacity of 400MW. Capital Power has a comprehensive land reclamation plan in place to return mined land back in to agricultural space.

name: Genesee #2
info: Unit 2 of the Genesee power station has been in operation since 1994. It has a maximum capacity of 400MW. Capital Power has a comprehensive land reclamation plan in place to return mined land back in to agricultural space.

name: Genesee #3
info: Unit 3 of the Genesee power station has been in operation since 2005, and is one of the most advanced, fuel-efficient, and environmentally-progressive coal-fired facilities in Canada. It has a maximum capacity of 466MW. It is also Canada's first power generation facility to use supercritical combustion technology for greater fuel efficiency and lower emissions.

name: H.R. Milner
info: H.R. Milner been in operation since 1972 and uses a dual fuel steam turbine generator capable of burning both natural gas and coal. It has a maximum capacity of 144MW.

name: Keephills #1
info: Keephills #1 has been in operation since 1983 and is one part of a three unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 395MW

name: Keephills #2
info: Keephills #2 has been in operation since 1983 and is one part of a three unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 395MW

name: Keephills #3
info: Keephills #3 has been in operation since 2011, and is one of Canada’s largest and cleanest coal-fired facilities and one of the most advanced facilities of its kind in the world. It was built to replace the previously existing Wabamun 4 station

name: Sheerness #1
location: Veterans Memorial Hwy, Sunnynook, AB T0J 3J0
info: Sheerness #1 has been in operation since 1986, and is one part of a two unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400MW, and has received its registration with the International Organization for Standardization’s Model for environmental management systems under ISO 14001.

name: Sheerness #2
location: Veterans Memorial Hwy, Sunnynook, AB T0J 3J0
info: Sheerness #2 has been in operation since 1990, and is one part of a two unit station. It has a maximum capacity of 400MW and has received its registration with the International Organization for Standardization’s Model for environmental management systems under ISO 14001.

name: Sundance #3
info: Sundancee #3 was built in 1976 and is one unit of a now five part station after Sundance #1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 368MW.

name: Sundance #4
info: Sundance #4 wass built in 1977 and is one unit of a now five part station after Sundance #1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 406MW.

name: Sundance #5
info: Sundace #5 was built in 1978 and is one unit of a now five part station after Sundance #1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 406MW.

name: Sundance #6
info: Sundance #6 was built in 1980 and is one unit of a now five part station after Sundance #1 was decommissioned in January 2018. It has a maximum capacity of 401MW.

name: Bighorn Hydro
info: Bighorn Hydro been in operation since 1972 and is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes to balance out shortages due to unexpected outages or to provide power at times of high demand. It has a maximum capacity of 120MW.

name: Bow River Hydro
info: Bow River Hydro was built in 1954 and is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes to balance out shortages due to unexpected outages or to provide power at times of high demand. It has a maximum capacity of 320MW.

name: Brazeau Hydro
info: Brazeau Hydro was built in 1965 and is Transalta's biggest hydro plant. It is primarily used to introduce hydro power within minutes to balance out shortages due to unexpected outages, or to provide power at times of high demand. It has a maximum capacity of 350MW

name: CUPC Oldman River
info: CUPC Oldman River was built is 2003 and was selected by Alberta Environment to develop the project at the existing dam site near Pincher Creek. it has a maximum capacity of 32MW

name: Chin Chute
info: Chin Chute is a small scale irrigation pipe turbine with a maximum capacity of 15MW.

name: Dickson Dam
info: Dickson Dam was built in 1992. The dam was created to control for floods and low winter flows, improve quality of the river, and create a recreational resource and to provide a reliable, year-round water supply. It has a maximum capacity of 15MW.

name: Irrican Hydro
info: Irrican Hydro was built in 1896 and is a small scale run-of-canal hydro plant in southern Alberta on the St. Mary’s Irrigation System.

name: Raymond Reservoir
info: A small hydro plant located beside the Raymond Reservoir, it was built in 1994. And has a maximum capacity of 21MW.

name: Taylor Hydro
info: Taylor Hydro was built in 2000, and operates during the six-month irrigation season each year from April to October. It has a maximum capcity of 14MW.

name: Ardenville Wind
info: Ardenville Wind was built in 2010 and is comprised of 23 80m wind turbines. It has a maximum capacity of 167MW

name: BUL1 Bull Creek
info: BUL1 Bull Creek was built in 2015 and is comprised of 17 GE wind turbines with a combined maximum capacity of 29MW.

name: BUL2 Bull Creek
info: BUL2 Bull Creek was built in 2015 and is comprised of 17 GE wind turbines with a combined maximum capacity of 29MW.

name: Blackspring Ridge
info: Blackspring Ridge was built in 2014 and is comprised of 166 turbines and is the largest investment of renewable energy in Western Canada. It has a maximum capacity of 300MW.

name: Blue Trail Wind
info: Blue Trail was built in 2009 and is comprised of 22, 3MW towers. It has a total maximum capacity of 167MW.

name: Castle River #1
info: Castle River began operating in 1997 with more units being installed between 2000 and 2001. It is comprised of 60 turbines and seven addition turbines located nearby with a total maximum capacity of 44MW.

name: Castle Rock Wind Farm
info: Castle Rock Wind Farm began operation in 2012 and is comprised of 33 turbines, with a total maximum capacity of 77MW.  It will allow for over 130,000 tonnes of CO2 to be avoided.

name: Cowley Ridge
info: Cowley Ridge wind farm was decommissioned in the spring of 2016.

name: Enmax Taber
info: The Taber Wind farm has been in operation since 2007. It is comprised of 37 Enercon Turibines, which are one of the most sofisticated turbine in the world. It has a total maximum capacity of 81MW.

name: Ghost Pine
info: Ghost Pine Wind farm was built in 2010, it is comprised of 51 turbines that are capable of generating enough power for 24 - 300 homes. it has a total maximum capacity of 82MW.

name: Halkirk Wind Power Facility
info: Built in 2012, the Halkirk Wind Power Facility is comprised of 83 Vestas-Canadian Wind Technology Inc. turbines. it has a total maximum capacity of 150MW.

name: Kettles Hill
info: Kettles Hill was built in 2 phases spread over 2016 and 2017. It contains 35 turbines with a combined maximum capacity of 63MW.

name: McBride Lake Windfarm
info: Built in 2003, the McBride Lake Windfarm has 114 Vesta turbines and creates enough electricity to reduce carbon dioxide emmissions by 164,500 tonnes annually. It has a total maximum capacity of 75MW.

name: Oldman 2 Wind Farm 1
info: Built in 2004, ownership of the Oldman 2 Wind Farm 1 transitioned over to IKEA group in 2014 as part of their initiative to has a carbon footprint of zero. it has a total maximum capacity to 46MW.

name: Soderglen Wind
info: Built in 2006, Soderglen Wind is compirsed of  47 turbines, each 65m tall. It has a total maximum capacity of 71MW.

name: Summerview 1
info: Built in 2004, it is comprised of 33 67me turbines. Ut has a total maximum capacity of 66MW.

name: Summerview 2
info: Built in 2010, Summerview 2 is the second unit for the Summerview Project. Comprised of 22 turbines, it has a total maximum capacity of 66MW.

name: Suncor Chin Chute
info: Built in 2006, and with 20 turbines, the Chin Chute wind farm has the capability of generating power of 11,000 homes. and has a total maximum capacity of 30MW.
owner: Suncor Energy Products, Inc., Enbridge Inc., and Acciona

name: Suncor Magrath
info: Built in 2004 with 20 turbines, Suncor Magrath is capable of offsetting 70,000 tonnes of carbon dioxide per year and has a maximum capacity of 30MW.
owner: Suncor Energy Products, Inc., Enbridge Inc., and Acciona

name: Wintering Hills
info: Built in 2011, Wintering Hills is comprised of 55 turbines and has a total maximum capacity of 88MW.

name: APF Athabasca
info: APF Athabasca was built in 1993 and continued operation until 2012. It is a biomass plant and had a maximum capacity of 131MW.

name: Brooks Solar
info: Built in 2017, Brooks 1 includes 50,000 solar panels, and is Western Canada's first utility scale solar project.

name: Cancarb Medicine Hat
info: Cancarb is a leader in the development and manufacturing of Thermal Carbon Black. The plant has a maximum capacity of 42MW.

name: DAI1 Daishowa
info: DAI1 Daishowa is a biomass plant added to the Diashowa Pulp Factory. It has a maximum capacity of 52MW.

name: Gold Creek Facility
info: Built in 1999, the Gold Creek Facility is a waste-heat generation facility with a maximum capacity of 5MW.

name: Grande Prairie EcoPower
info: Built in 2005, Grande Prairie EcoPower is a biomass plant with a maximum capacity of 25MW.

name: NRGreen
info: Operating as a heat recovery plant, NRGreen works along the Alliance Pipline, and in conjunction with five other similar plants. it has a maximum capacity of 16MW.

name: Slave Lake
info: The Slave Lake Pulp Mill is able to create up to 6MW of power using methane from pulp production.

name: Weldwood #1
info: Using wood waste from surrounding lumber mills, the biomass plant has a maximum capacity of 50MW.

name: Westlock
info: Built in 1997, the Westlock plant utilizes recycled woody biomass material to generate a maximum of 46MW.

name: Weyerhaeuser
info: Built as a section of the Grande Praire Pulp Mill, it utilizes the waste from the mill to create power from biomass. It has a maximum capacity of 48MW.

name: Whitecourt Power
info: Built in 2012, the Whitecourt Power Biomass Plant has earned the federal governments EcoLogo designation. It has a maximum capacity of 25MW.

name: AB Newsprint
info: The AB Newsprint facility has a generating capacity of 65 MW.

name: AltaGas Bantry
info: Bantry uses natural gas fired electrical peaking generators and total maximum capacity of 7MW

name: AltaGas Parkland
info: Parkland uses natural gas fired electrical peaking generators. It has a total maximum capacity of 10MW

name: Bellshill Power Centre
info: Bellshill Power Centre was built in 2015 with a total capacity of 5.6 MW.

name: Carson Creek
info: Carson Creek is a 15MW simple cycle gas turbine that operates during peak demand periods.

name: Clover Bar Evergy Centre - Unit 1
info: Clover Bar Evergy Centre #1 is one of three highly-efficient natural-gas turbines power up from standstill to full load in 10 minutes to give Capital Power flexibility to respo​nd to sudden changes in supply and demand. All three units produce a combined capacity of 243MW.

name: Clover Bar Evergy Centre - Unit 2
info: Clover Bar Evergy Centre #2 is one of three highly-efficient natural-gas turbines power up from standstill to full load in 10 minutes to give Capital Power flexibility to respo​nd to sudden changes in supply and demand. All three units produce a combined capacity of 243MW.

name: Clover Bar Evergy Centre - Unit 3
info: Clover Bar Evergy Centre  #3 is one of three highly-efficient natural-gas turbines power up from standstill to full load in 10 minutes to give Capital Power flexibility to respo​nd to sudden changes in supply and demand. All three units produce a combined capacity of 243MW.

name: Crossfield Energy Centre #1
info: Built in 2009, all three centres have a combined total capacity of 120MW.

name: Crossfield Energy Centre #2
info: Built in 2009, all three centres have a combined total capacity of 120MW.

name: Crossfield Energy Centre #3
info: Built in 2009, all three centres have a combined total capacity of 120MW.

name: Drywood
info: Built in 2000 with a total capacity of 6MW.

name: High River
info: The High River facaility has a capacity of approximately 500 MW.

name: House Mountain Distributed Generation Facility
info: The House Mountain Distributed Generation Facility is a 6 megawatt (MW) natural gas-fired power facility

name: Judy Creek
info: Judy Creek is a 15MW simple cycle gas faciliy that operates during peak hours.

name: Lethbridge Burdett
info: Built in 2001, the Lethbridge Burdett plant has a capacity of 7MW.

name: Lethbridge Coaldale
info: Built in 2001 the Lethbridge Coaldale plant a capacity of 6MW.

name: Lethbridge Taber
info: Built in 2001, the Lethbridge Taber has a capacity of 8MW.

name: NPC1 Denis St. Pierre (NPC1)
info: n/a

name: NPC2 JL Landry (NPC2)
info: n/a

name: Northern Prairie Power Project
info: Northern Prairie Power Project is a natural gas plant with a capacity of 85MW

name: Poplar Hill Generating Plant
info: The 45 megawatt Poplar Hill Generating Plant near Grande Prairie provides northwest Alberta with necessary transmission system support and is an important source of additional electric energy for the Alberta grid.

name: Rainbow #5
info: Rainbow #5 is a 90 megawatt gas-fired cogeneration and peaking facility is adjacent to a gas plant owned and operated by Husky Oil at Rainbow Lake,

name: Ralston
info: The Ralston plant has a maximum capacity of 20 MW.

name: Valley View #1
info: Valley View generation plants have a combined total capacity of 90MW.

name: Valley View 2
info: Valley View generation plants have a combined total capacity of 90MW.

name: West Cadotte
info: The West Cadotte plant has a total capacity of 4MW

name: ATCO Scotford Upgrader
info: The ATCO Scotford Upgrader was constructed to provide steam and electricity to meet the thermal and power needs of the Athabasca Oilsands Upgrader. Two thirds of the power is used for the oilsands with the surplus being sold to Alberta Power pool. It has a maximum capacity of 195MW.

name: Air Liquide Scotford #1
info: Air Liquide Scotford #1 is a gas power plant, with a maximum capacity of 96MW.

name: AltaGas Harmattan
info: The Harmattan Gas Processing Complex processes and extracts gas. It is one of the largest gas plants in Alberta. And has a maximum capacity of 45MW.

name: Base Plant
info: Located at Suncor's Oilsands, the Base Plant has a maximum capacity of 50MW.

name: Bear Creek 1
info: Is a combined-cycle cogeneration with steam augmentation from a wood waste boiler. It has a maximum capacity of 64MW.

name: Bear Creek 2
info: Bear Creek 2 is a combined-cycle cogeneration with steam augmentation from a wood waste boiler. It has a maximum capacity of 64MW.

name: BuckLake
info: Built in 1961, The BuckLake Plant receives its raw gas from numerous wells connected by an extensive network of pipelines. It has with a maximum capacity of 5MW

name: CNRL Horizon
info: CNRL Horizon has a maximum capacity of 203MW.

name: Camrose
info: Camrose has a maximum capacity of 10MW.

name: Carseland Cogen
info: Carseland Cogen is a cogeneration plant that supplies Alberta with up to 95MW.

name: Christina Lake
info: Christina Lake uses cogeneration and has a maximum capacity of 100MW.

name: Dow Hydrocarbon
info: Dow Hydrocarbonvturns crude oil and natural gas based raw material into basic chemical building blocks and intermediate products for Dow's downstream derivative partners. It has a maximum capacity of 326MW.

name: Edson
info: In the process of being improved upon, this plant will eventually be able to produce 900MW of power but at the moment has a maximum capacity of 13MW.

name: Firebag
info: Built in 2003, the Firebag plant has a maximum capacity of 473MW and is one on the few power plants located north of the 56th parallel.

name: Fort Hills
info: Fort Hills is capable of sustaining a production of 14,500 tonnes of oil sand per hour. It has a maximum capacity of 199MW. Fort Hills is located on the Athabasca Oil Sands.

name: Foster Creek
info: As Cenovus's first oil sand project, they make use of SAGD to drill and pump the oil to the surface. It has a maximum capacity of 98MW.

name: Joffre #1
info: Joffre #1 is a natural gas-fired cogeneration plant to meet the substantial steam and electric energy needs of NOVA’s world-class petrochemical facility, selling excess power in the Alberta power pool. It has a maximum capacity of 474MW.

name: Kearl
info: The Kearl Oilsands are located near the Athanbasca oilsands, and has a maximum capacity of 84MW.

name: Lindbergh
info: Lindbergh was built in 2012 as a steam injection pilot project. It has a maximum capacity of 16MW.

name: MEG1 Christina Lake
info: A Canadian oil sands company focused on sustainable in the development and production in the Southern Athabasca region of Alberta. It has a maximum capacity of 202MW.

name: MacKay River
info: MacKay River is an industrial cogeneration project that is situated on Suncor’s MacKay River oilsands development. it has a maximum capacity of 207MW.

name: Mahkeses
info: Opened for production in the 1960s, it is one Canada's oldest power plants and one of the largest thermal in-situ heavy oil operations in the world. it has a maximum capacity of 180MW.

name: Muskeg River
info: Muskeg River is a cogeneration plant provides steam and electricity to meet the requirements of the Muskeg River Mine. Any electricity generated and not used at the mine is sold into the Power Pool of Alberta. It has a maximum capacity of 202MW.

name: Nabiye
info: Built in 2004 as a part of Imperial Oil's 13 phase bitumun production. it has a maximum capacity of 195MW.

name: Nexen Inc #2
info: Nexen Inc #2 has a maximum capacity of 220MW.

name: Poplar Creek
info: Poplar Creek is gas-fired turbines at Suncor’s oil sands site near Fort McMurray. TransAlta provides Suncor with centralized monitoring, diagnostics and technical support to maximize performance and reliability of plant equipment. It has a maximum capacity of 376MW.

name: Primrose #1
info: Primrose has a maximum capacity of 100MW and was Alberta’s first independent power project on stream in 1998 in the newly deregulated market.

name: Rainbow Lake #1
info: Rainbow Lake #1 has been decommissioned as of November 2016

name: Redwater Cogen
info: The plant is customized to use a blend of natural gas and regeneration gas, a product of Williams Energy’s fractionation business, to fuel the gas turbine, and has a maximum capacity of 46MW.

name: Shell Caroline
info: The Shell Caroline plant is part of the Shell Caroline Complex and has a maximum capacity of 19MW.

name: Syncrude #1
info: As one of the biggest operators in Canada's Oil sands it creates up to 510MW of power for Alberta.

name: University of Calgary Generator
info: The University Cogeneration plant will allow for the university to cut its CO2 emissions by half. and has a maximum capacity of 12MW.

name: University of Alberta
info: the University of Alberta plant has a maximum capacity of 39MW, and is used to heat the campus buildings.

name: ENMAX Calgary Energy Centre
info: The Calgary Energy Center is a combined cycle powerplant located on the northeast corner of Calgary Alberta. Powered by a single Westinghouse W502-FD2 combustion turbine. It has a maximum capacity of 320MW.

name: Cavalier
info: The Cavalier Energy Centre and the Balzac Facility are part of a larger generation portfolio intended to help meet the growing electricity needs of our customers across Alberta. It has a maximum capacity of 120MW.

name: Fort Nelson
info: Another of BC Hydro's alternative energy sources is thermal generation. This involves burning fuel to produce hot gases or steam to drive gas or steam turbines that are connected to generators. with a maximum capacity of 73MW being sent to Alberta.

name: Medicine Hat #1
info: Opened in 2017, Medicine Hat #1 is used to supply power to the city. It has a maximum capacity of 255MW.

name: Nexen Inc #1
info: The Balzac Power Station is a natural gas-fired combined cycle power generation facility capable of producing up to 120MW, approximately enough to power 100,000 residential homes

name: Shepard
info: Shepard is Alberta's largest natural gas-fuelled power facility. it has a maximum capacity of 860MW.
